title: Keybase client: downloaded executables lack "com.apple.quarantine" meta-attribute [macOS]
vulnerability_information:
## Summary

1. Missing quarantine attribute for downloaded files allows remote attacker to send executable file that won't be checked by Gatekeeper (codesign bypass). 

2. Since sent executable files lack `com.apple.quarantine` meta-attribute, no alert about launching executable file from the web will be shown to user.

3. That means, dblclick on file in Finder.app (or any similar gesture to launch the file) immediately launches the attacker's file.

## PoC

1. Attacker sends `exploit.terminal` to the victim (file is unsigned)
2. Victim opens `exploit.terminal`
3. No alert from Gatekeeper about unsigned executable
4. No alert about running executable file downloaded from the web
5. Shell commands from `exploit.terminal` execute with user-level privileges.

> NOTE: if victim is sudoer with no pass, attacker can insert `sudo` commands in `*.terminal` file and gain `root` permissions.

Screencast + `exploit.terminal` file sample attached.

> Screencast: `xattr <file>` shows apple-specific meta-attributes like `com.apple.quarantine`

## Impact

Quarantine + codesigning are basic security mechanisms, which prevents user/device from running untrusted executables.

Keybase allows to send **messages** and share **KBFS** with **any Keybase user** (!), that allows attacker to make a massive spam of `.terminal` files with malicious payload.
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary

  1. Missing quarantine attribute for downloaded files allows remote attacker to send executable file that won't be checked by Gatekeeper (codesign bypass).

  2. Since sent executable files lack com.apple.quarantine meta-attribute, no alert about launching executable file from the web will be shown to user.

  3. That means, dblclick on file in Finder.app (or any similar gesture to launch the file) immediately launches the attacker's file.

PoC

  1. Attacker sends exploit.terminal to the victim (file is unsigned)
  2. Victim opens exploit.terminal
  3. No alert from Gatekeeper about unsigned executable
  4. No alert about running executable file downloaded from the web
  5. Shell commands from exploit.terminal execute with user-level privileges.

NOTE: if victim is sudoer with no pass, attacker can insert sudo commands in *.terminal file and gain root permissions.

Screencast + exploit.terminal file sample attached.

Screencast: xattr <file> shows apple-specific meta-attributes like com.apple.quarantine

Impact

Quarantine + codesigning are basic security mechanisms, which prevents user/device from running untrusted executables.

Keybase allows to send messages and share KBFS with any Keybase user (!), that allows attacker to make a massive spam of .terminal files with malicious payload.

activities.message: Question: which download mechanism did you test for this? KBFS Finder integration, chat downloads or files tab in the app?
activities.markdown_message: Question: which download mechanism did you test for this? KBFS Finder integration, chat downloads or files tab in the app?

activities.message:
I used chat downloads (screencast). That also means files tab is vulnerable too because it's the same Electron app.
> For corresponding quarantine header check Chrome's Info.plist

From my observations, sending files over KBFS doesn't attach any meta-attributes, so KBFS must be vulnerable too. I'm going to check it now.
activities.markdown_message:
I used chat downloads (screencast). That also means files tab is vulnerable too because it's the same Electron app.

For corresponding quarantine header check Chrome's Info.plist

From my observations, sending files over KBFS doesn't attach any meta-attributes, so KBFS must be vulnerable too. I'm going to check it now.

activities.message:
I was able to repro KBFS.

KBFS:
1. Send file to KBFS
2. launch file from KBFS (/Keybase/(private|public)/<username>)

Slack uses Quarantine - it's easy to check
Dropbox doesn't, I guess because their folders are considered as a "trusted space". 

> I'm working on reporting this issue to multiple providers: Skype/WhatsApp/Signal/Dropbox, so I hope this report won't make them fix this problem before my report to them :)

activities.message:
@maxtaco As I understand, KBFS should respect MOTW ("mark of the web") on Windows too. MOTW - is the same defensive mechanism as GateKeeper and Quarantine

I've not checked Windows yet (just started pulling a VM), do I need to report it as a separate vulnerability?
activities.markdown_message:
@maxtaco As I understand, KBFS should respect MOTW ("mark of the web") on Windows too. MOTW - is the same defensive mechanism as GateKeeper and Quarantine

I've not checked Windows yet (just started pulling a VM), do I need to report it as a separate vulnerability?

activities.message: It was part of our plan internally too to examine Windows, etc. Thanks!
activities.markdown_message: It was part of our plan internally too to examine Windows, etc. Thanks!

activities.message:
In a case MOTW is not set by your FUSE implementation or any Win misbehavior, and you're going to add them in your implementation:

- Chrome's MOTW blacklist is available [here](https://cs.chromium.org/chromium/src/chrome/browser/resources/safe_browsing/download_file_types.asciipb)

- FF has a similar [blacklist](https://searchfox.org/mozilla-central/source/xpcom/io/nsLocalFileWin.cpp#2901), easier to copy-paste, but it's not complete.

- Adobe has a [huge blacklist for paranoids](https://gist.github.com/rxwx/8834cee60e077531c4db2f260ee55e2a)

- (my repo: [dangerous-file-extensions](https://github.com/Metnew/dangerous-file-extensions) Win files are almost the same as in Chromium )

Thanks for replying, Keybase is awesome!
activities.markdown_message:
In a case MOTW is not set by your FUSE implementation or any Win misbehavior, and you're going to add them in your implementation:

  • Chrome's MOTW blacklist is available here

  • FF has a similar blacklist, easier to copy-paste, but it's not complete.

  • Adobe has a huge blacklist for paranoids

  • (my repo: dangerous-file-extensions Win files are almost the same as in Chromium )

Thanks for replying, Keybase is awesome!

activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
Hi @maxtaco!

Any updates on this? Two months passed since the reporting date.

Also, I'd like to post an article about Quarantine issues in applications and highlight your effort in fixing this bug. Only two companies decided to fix this issue so far;  resolutions on other three reports are still pending.

> Slack appears to be vulnerable too, but only if it the app was downloaded from the official website, not from AppStore
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @maxtaco!

Any updates on this? Two months passed since the reporting date.

Also, I'd like to post an article about Quarantine issues in applications and highlight your effort in fixing this bug. Only two companies decided to fix this issue so far; resolutions on other three reports are still pending.

Slack appears to be vulnerable too, but only if it the app was downloaded from the official website, not from AppStore

activities.message:
Hi @maxtaco, I found a better attack scenario:

1. Silently share a file with victim  (check `/keybase/private/metnew,max`
2. Drop an executable in this folder
3. Send a crafted `.url` file to victim
4. Victim opens `.url` file -> RCE

The main trick is that crafted `.url` files may run arbitrary executables by the path on the system.
Files located in Keybase have known paths.
`.url` files aren't blocked by browsers(Chrome/FF/Safari) and could be sent using messengers, mail apps, browsers, file storages, <any_app>.
 
I've made a private shared folder `metnew,max` with PoC `x.url` and `exploit.terminal`

I know that Keybase almost patched the bug, but I think such attack scenario may increase severity to critical retroactively: that's 1-click RCE.

> Hardcoded paths allow tricking users into running arbitrary executables shared in Keybase even with quarantine. Not sure, need some bypass for that.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @maxtaco, I found a better attack scenario:

  1. Silently share a file with victim (check /keybase/private/metnew,max
  2. Drop an executable in this folder
  3. Send a crafted .url file to victim
  4. Victim opens .url file -> RCE

The main trick is that crafted .url files may run arbitrary executables by the path on the system.
Files located in Keybase have known paths.
.url files aren't blocked by browsers(Chrome/FF/Safari) and could be sent using messengers, mail apps, browsers, file storages, <any_app>.

I've made a private shared folder metnew,max with PoC x.url and exploit.terminal

I know that Keybase almost patched the bug, but I think such attack scenario may increase severity to critical retroactively: that's 1-click RCE.

Hardcoded paths allow tricking users into running arbitrary executables shared in Keybase even with quarantine. Not sure, need some bypass for that.

activities.message:
Hi, thanks for the follow-up. I'm not sure I fully understand.  The victim of this attack needs to:

1. Download the link as an attachment from chat (or something)
2. Double click on the downloaded file in the finder (x.url)

How is this different from sending someone the malware just from the chat? Is there anyway that downloading x.url from the internet also executes it without further action? That's what I don't understand.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi, thanks for the follow-up. I'm not sure I fully understand. The victim of this attack needs to:

  1. Download the link as an attachment from chat (or something)
  2. Double click on the downloaded file in the finder (x.url)

How is this different from sending someone the malware just from the chat? Is there anyway that downloading x.url from the internet also executes it without further action? That's what I don't understand.

activities.message:
Yeah, `.url` files downloaded from web could launch files on FS.
Attaching a PoC (h1 renames `.url` to `.txt`)
activities.markdown_message:
Yeah, .url files downloaded from web could launch files on FS.
Attaching a PoC (h1 renames .url to .txt)

activities.message:
Sorry, misunderstand your question
The key thing here is that the issue isn't connected to Keybase client only.
The victim may receive a `.url` file from mail, browser, other messengers
activities.markdown_message:
Sorry, misunderstand your question
The key thing here is that the issue isn't connected to Keybase client only.
The victim may receive a .url file from mail, browser, other messengers

activities.message: But in either mail or browser, clicking on that x.url file downloads it to Downloads, and then the user needs to double-click on it, no?
activities.markdown_message: But in either mail or browser, clicking on that x.url file downloads it to Downloads, and then the user needs to double-click on it, no?

activities.message:
Yes, it anyway requires a click on `.url` file. However:
1. the victim doesn't explicitly click on an executable file - that's very important.
2. Browsers/mail clients allow opening files directly: send `.url` over mail -> victim opens in `Mail.app` (no download step) -> arbitrary code gets executed. For browsers, almost same: it's likely the file will be opened from Chrome downloads bar or in FF via "Open" button.

> For messengers: open `x.url` from Telegram/Skype UI -> RCE
> `.url` files are generally treated as internet shortcuts

I hope you get my point, I may record a screencast if required
activities.markdown_message:
Yes, it anyway requires a click on .url file. However:

  1. the victim doesn't explicitly click on an executable file - that's very important.
  2. Browsers/mail clients allow opening files directly: send .url over mail -> victim opens in Mail.app (no download step) -> arbitrary code gets executed. For browsers, almost same: it's likely the file will be opened from Chrome downloads bar or in FF via "Open" button.

For messengers: open x.url from Telegram/Skype UI -> RCE
.url files are generally treated as internet shortcuts

I hope you get my point, I may record a screencast if required

activities.message: I see, so you're saying is that our previous lack of quarantine protection was a way for an attacker to get around the correct quarantine protection of other applications.
activities.markdown_message: I see, so you're saying is that our previous lack of quarantine protection was a way for an attacker to get around the correct quarantine protection of other applications.

activities.message:
For me it's (sorry for duplicating this):

1. Fixed paths in Keybase => attacker always knows the path to malicious executable
2. it's easy to open this malicious executable via ".url"
3. `.url` opens anywhere and isn't blocked by other apps -> RCE (something that I demonstrated on the screencast)

pretty silent and reliable RCE without strange `.terminal` files and user interaction on macOS.
activities.markdown_message:

  2. it's easy to open this malicious executable via ".url"
  3. .url opens anywhere and isn't blocked by other apps -> RCE (something that I demonstrated on the screencast)

pretty silent and reliable RCE without strange .terminal files and user interaction on macOS.

> 1. Share malicious file with every follower and send them `.url` (e.g. via Twitter) pointing to the malicious file 
> 2. If RCE -> return to 1
activities.markdown_message:
Keybase worm (if no quarantine)

  1. Share malicious file with every follower and send them .url (e.g. via Twitter) pointing to the malicious file
  2. If RCE -> return to 1

activities.message: I'd agree with you if it took *one* click but in every example you've sent me, it takes *two* --- one to download the ".url" file, and another to open it.
activities.markdown_message: I'd agree with you if it took one click but in every example you've sent me, it takes two --- one to download the ".url" file, and another to open it.

activities.message:
macOS version is fixed - tested on a real device.
Windows has MOTW + I see in PRs you've implemented protection for DLL hijacking - only static analysis of source code and Github.

Seems fixed to me.

Could we not disclose all the report details publicly for a while?
Telegram is still working on a patch.

I believe we could make a full disclosure in 1-2 weeks.

activities.message:
I really don't want to nag about bounty and severity, just want to make sure we're on the same page. 

The original attack scenario really was estimated as "Medium", but later I provided an attack scenario which requires only 1 click:
1. silently sync a file with victim
2. auto-download a shortcut file through browser
3. victim should do 1 click on this file in "Downloads" bar

I later messaged you on Keybase and showed the PoC, and you said that it makes no sense to change the "Severity" but you'll consider my additional research when awarding the bounty.

My Keybase: @metnew
Message is dated 24 Jan 2019

summaries.content:
Insufficient quarantine handling in Keybase allowed a remote attacker to execute code on a target macOS device via shortcut file pointing to the synced asset. (1 click RCE via file shortcut)
Paths to synced files is known to attacker: `/keybase/public/attacker,victim/<file>`

The vulnerability initially was reported for macOS. However, Keybase team found that Windows version has a similar issue with MOTW additionally leading to DLL hijacking scenarios.

I want to thank the @keybase team for giving a chance to other companies to patch their products by not disclosing this report for a while.
summaries.content_html:
Insufficient quarantine handling in Keybase allowed a remote attacker to execute code on a target macOS device via shortcut file pointing to the synced asset. (1 click RCE via file shortcut)
Paths to synced files is known to attacker: /keybase/public/attacker,victim/<file>

The vulnerability initially was reported for macOS. However, Keybase team found that Windows version has a similar issue with MOTW additionally leading to DLL hijacking scenarios.

I want to thank the @keybase team for giving a chance to other companies to patch their products by not disclosing this report for a while.
